rationale: `avg_ber` is BER-like (min=0, max=0.00352, zero%=0.03, skew≈-0.35). BERs span orders of magnitude; applying `-log10(x+1e-12)` spreads small values and makes this feature numerically well-scaled. Then standardize for models sensitive to feature scale (linear models, kNN, neural nets).

`num_links` is a low-cardinality integer count (nunique≈9). You can keep it numeric (scaled) or one-hot encode if you suspect non-linear jumps.
`num_spans` is count-like; standardization keeps it comparable to other features for gradient-based models.
`dst_degree` is a low-cardinality integer count (nunique≈3). You can keep it numeric (scaled) or one-hot encode if you suspect non-linear jumps.

`freq` has low-ish cardinality on a fixed grid (nunique≈96); treating it as continuous implies a linear ordering that usually does not reflect channel identity. Prefer categorical encoding.
